Code¶

Model¶

Data Model for the Feeder Reader.

class model.Channel(*, title: str, link: pydantic_core._pydantic_core.Url)¶

Overall Channel summary.

<rss version="2.0">
<channel>
<title>Eastern District of New York Filings Entries on cases</title>
<link>https://ecf.nyed.uscourts.gov</link>
<description>Public Filings in the last 24 Hours</description>
<lastBuildDate>Thu, 28 Dec 2023 21:20:01 GMT</lastBuildDate>
...
</channel>
</rss>

<description>
<![CDATA[ [Quality Control Check - Summons] Sookra v. Berkeley Carroll School et al ]]>
</description>
<link>https://ecf.nyed.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/DktRpt.pl?508001</link>
</item>

Reader¶

Reader portion of the Feeder Reader.

From the config.toml, get a list of feeds.

Get the current RSS document, and parse to extract Channel and Item details.

Note that feeds are updated to have only the previous 24 hours of content. This should be run at least once each day, twice to be sure nothing is missed.

reader.feed_iter(document: xml.etree.ElementTree.Element) → collections.abc.Iterator[model.USCourtItem | model.Channel]¶

Iterate through the <channel><item>…</item></channel> structure of an <rss>. This emits a sequence of Channel and USCourtItem objects from the XML.

reader.capture(writer: storage.Storage, feed: collections.abc.Iterator[model.USCourtItem | model.Channel]) → None¶

Save this feed JSON files {item.date}/{item.time.hour}/items.json.

reader.reader() → None¶
reader.cleaner() → None¶

Filter¶

Filter portion of Feeder Reader.

From the config.toml, get a list of interesting docket numbers.

This keeps an cache of items that are interesting.

It scanes the entire downloaded collection of items looking for “interesting” items. It compares those with the cache to see if there have been changes.

Changes trigger notification – SMTP email or an SNS.

filter.match_items(storage: storage.Storage, path: tuple[str, ...], targets: list[str], history: set[model.USCourtItemDetail], counts: collections.Counter[str]) → collections.abc.Iterator[model.USCourtItemDetail]¶

A sequence of filters…

Sadly, we’ve pre-empted the name filter() in this module.

source = cast(list[USCourtItemDetail], storage.read_json(path, USCourtItemDetail))
has_docket = filter(lambda item: item.item.docket, source)
has_target = filter(lambda item: any(d in item.item.docket.lower() for d in targets), has_docket)
novel = filter(lambda item: item not in history, has_target)
filter.filter() → None¶

Writer¶

Writer portion of Feeder Reader.

From the config.toml, get a desired output format.

This reads all the unique items from the data cache, organizes them, and then emits all of them using the selected template.

It also looks for a filter.json with the dockets considered interesting by the filter.

writer.load_indices(storage: storage.Storage) → dict[str, dict[str, list[model.USCourtItemDetail]]]¶
writer.write_csv(indices: dict[str, dict[str, list[model.USCourtItemDetail]]]) → None¶
writer.paginate_keys(keys: list[Any], page_size: int) → list[tuple[int, tuple[int, int]]]¶
writer.write_template(logger: logging.Logger, output: storage.Storage, format: str, page_size: int, indices: dict[str, dict[str, list[model.USCourtItemDetail]]]) → None¶
writer.writer() → None¶

Monitor¶

Define and execute a periodic schedule of FeederReader work.

monitor.feeder_reader() → None¶

The FeederReader Processing.

monitor.main() → None¶

Common¶

Common functions and classes used throughout Feeder Reader.

common.get_config(**section: dict[str, Any]) → dict[str, Any]¶

Read THE config.toml config file, if present.

Update the DEFAULTS with config file updated with any section-level dictionaries.

Use a call like this:

common.get_config(writer = {'format': 'csv'})

to override the config file with command-line options.
